title: "Stein's Paradox"
output: html_notebook

Define variables and functions needed
```{r}
library(ggplot2)


p <- 20
eucl_len <- function(x) {
  sqrt(sum(x^2))
}


simulate <- function(means) {
  p <- length(means)
  JS_loss <- c()
  posJS_loss <- c()
  mean_shift_loss <- c()
  lim_tr_loss <- c()
  intuitive_loss <- c()
  
  
  for (i in 1:200){
  normal <- rnorm(means, means, 1) #Generate sample from normal distribution, independent

  ybar <- mean(normal)
  c <- 1 - (p-3)/eucl_len(normal - ybar)^2
  len_x <- eucl_len(normal)
  a <- p - 2 #minimises risk

  mean_shift <- ybar + c*(normal - ybar)
  JS <- (1 - a/len_x^2)*normal
  posJS <- 0*normal
  if (a < len_x^2){
    posJS <- JS
  }
  lim_tr <- c()
  for (i in 1:p){
    lim_tr[i] <- min(max(mean_shift[i], normal[i] - 1), normal[i] + 1) 
  }
  

  JS_loss <- c(JS_loss, eucl_len(JS - means)^2)
  posJS_loss <- c(posJS_loss, eucl_len(posJS - means)^2)
  mean_shift_loss <- c(mean_shift_loss, eucl_len(mean_shift - means)^2)
  lim_tr_loss <- c(lim_tr_loss, eucl_len(lim_tr - means)^2)
  intuitive_loss <- c(intuitive_loss, eucl_len(normal - means)^2)

    
    
}
  x <- list()
  x[[1]] <- JS_loss
  x[[2]] <- posJS_loss
  x[[3]] <- mean_shift_loss
  x[[4]] <- lim_tr_loss
  x[[5]] <- intuitive_loss

  
  return(x)
}

find_means <- function(x) {
  risk <- c()
  for (i in 1:length(x)) {
    risk[i] <- mean(x[[i]])
}
  return(risk)
}
```
Simulate risk for Unif(-1, 1) prior
```{r}
set.seed(267462)

means_unif <- runif(p, -1, 1)
unif <- simulate(means_unif)
names <- c("JS", "+ve JS", "Mean Shift", "Limited", "MLE")
barplot(find_means(unif), ylab = "Estimate of risk", names.arg = names, ylim = c(0, 20))
```
Simulate risk when extreme values are added
```{r}
set.seed(735284)
means_extreme <- c(runif(p-2, -1, 1), runif(2, 40, 100))
extreme <- simulate(means_extreme)
barplot(find_means(extreme), ylab = "Estimate of risk", names.arg = names, ylim = c(0, 20))
```
